details.title: Testing Convexity or Concavity of a Cumulated Hazard Rate

authors.affiliation: Lab. de Math., Univ. Paris Sud, Orsay

p: Cécile Durot received her Ph.D. (1997) in statistics from the University Paris-Sud, France. She is currently at the University Paris-Sud, Department of Mathematics. Her research interest includes nonparametric statistics under a shape restriction, and model selection.

authors.name: CÉcile Durot

details.abstract: In this paper, we build a statistical test of aging on a given period, in the increasing failure rate (IFR) or decreasing failure rate (DFR) sense. More precisely, we build a nonparametric test for the null hypothesis that a cumulated hazard rate is convex (or concave) on a given interval, against the alternative that it is not. The observations are right-censored data, and the censoring variables are possibly random with an unknown distribution. Theoretical properties of the statistical test are studied. It has asymptotic level alpha; and good asymptotic power against fixed, and local alternatives. The procedure is applied to two real data sets.

context.text: For this reason, many test statistics have been developed in the literature for testing exponentiality (which corresponds to the assumption of no aging) against different aging alternatives, [1], [2], [6], [16], [17], [23].

references.title: The NBUT class of life distributions

context.text: For this reason, many test statistics have been developed in the literature for testing exponentiality (which corresponds to the assumption of no aging) against different aging alternatives, [1], [2], [6], [16], [17], [23].

links.abstract: A new class of life distributions, namely new better than used in the total time on test transform ordering (NBUT), is introduced. The relationship of this class to other classes of life distributions, and closure properties under some reliability operations, are discussed. We provide a simple argument based on stochastic orders that the family of the NBUT distribution class is closed under the formation of series systems in case of independent identically distributed components. Behavior of thi...

references.text: I. A. Ahmad, M. Kayid, X. Li, "The NBUT class of life distributions", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 54, pp. 396-401, 2005.

references.title:
Useful periods for lifetime distributions with bathtub shaped
hazard rate functions

context.text: For instance, as in many reliability problems, its hazard rate may have a bathtub shape [4], or it could be eventually increasing [7], [20].

links.abstract: We propose computationally tractable formal mathematical definitions for the 'useful period' of lifetime distributions with bathtub shaped hazard rate functions. Detailed analysis of the reduced additive Weibull hazard rate function illustrates its utility for identifying such useful periods. Examples of several other bathtub shaped hazard rate functions are also presented with applications to lifetime data. The suggestion is made of defining and considering analogous 'stable periods' in the cas...

references.text: M. Bebbington, C. Lai, R. Zitikis, "Useful periods for lifetime distributions with bathtub shaped hazard rate functions", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 55, pp. 245-251, 2006.

references.title:
Comparison of expected failure times for
several replacement policies

context.text: This knowledge is useful, for instance, to choose an appropriate burn-in procedure, or replacement & maintenance policies, because the determination of optimal burn-in time, repair, or replacement age (which minimizes a given cost criterion, or maximizes a given performance measure) depends on the underlying aging class [5], [7], [8], [24].

links.abstract: Planned replacement policies are used to reduce the incidence of system failures, or to return a failed system to work. New better than used aging classes are commonly used in reliability theory to model situations in which the lifetime of a new unit is "better" than the lifetime of a used one. The purpose of this paper is to establish comparisons of expected failure times of an age (block) replacement policy, and a renewal process with no planned replacements when the lifetime of the unit is NB...

references.text: F. Belzunce, E. M. Ortega, J. M. Ruiz, "Comparison of expected failure times for several replacement policies", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 55, pp. 490-495, 2006.

For instance, as in many reliability problems, its hazard rate may have a bathtub shape [4], or it could be eventually increasing [7], [20].

links.abstract: In this paper, the problem of determining optimal burn-in time is considered under the general failure model. There are two types of failure in the general failure model. One is Type I failure (minor failure) which can be removed by a minimal repair, and the other is Type II failure (catastrophic failure) which can be removed only by a complete repair. In the researches on optimal burn-in, the assumption of a bathtub shaped failure rate function is commonly adopted. In this paper, upper bounds f...

references.text: J. H. Cha, "An extended model for optimal burn-in procedures", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 55, pp. 189-198, 2006.

references.title:
Optimal
allocation of minimal & perfect repairs under resource constraints

context.text: This knowledge is useful, for instance, to choose an appropriate burn-in procedure, or replacement & maintenance policies, because the determination of optimal burn-in time, repair, or replacement age (which minimizes a given cost criterion, or maximizes a given performance measure) depends on the underlying aging class [5], [7], [8], [24].

links.abstract: The effect of a repair of a complex system can usually be approximated by the following two types: minimal repair for which the system is restored to its functioning state with minimum effort, or perfect repair for which the system is replaced or repaired to a good-as-new state. When both types of repair are possible, an important problem is to determine the repair policy; that is, the type of repair which should be carried out after a failure. In this paper, an optimal allocation problem is stu...

references.text: L. Cui, W. Kuo, H. T. Loh, "Optimal allocation of minimal & perfect repairs under resource constraints", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 53, pp. 193-199, 2004.

references.title:
Nonparametric testing for a monotone hazard
function via normalized spacings

context.text: From our knowledge, the only papers where such a problem is studied are [11], and [13], where a statistical test for the IFR (or DFR) null hypothesis is proposed.
This problem is closely related to that in [11], and [13] because in the case of an IFR (or DFR) distribution, the null hypothesis should be accepted.
However, we consider a bounded interval \$[a,b)\$, whereas in [11], and [13], \$\Lambda\$ is convex (or concave) on the whole half-line \$[0,\infty)\$ under the null hypothesis.
Moreover, our sample is censored with a possibly unknown censoring distribution, whereas only the case of uncensored data is formally studied in [11], and [13].

references.text: I. Gijbels, N. Heckman, "Nonparametric testing for a monotone hazard function via normalized spacings", Nonparametr. Stat., vol. 16, pp. 463-477, 2004.

references.title: Testing for monotone increasing hazard rate

context.text: From our knowledge, the only papers where such a problem is studied are [11], and [13], where a statistical test for the IFR (or DFR) null hypothesis is proposed.
This problem is closely related to that in [11], and [13] because in the case of an IFR (or DFR) distribution, the null hypothesis should be accepted.
However, we consider a bounded interval \$[a,b)\$, whereas in [11], and [13], \$\Lambda\$ is convex (or concave) on the whole half-line \$[0,\infty)\$ under the null hypothesis.

links.abstract: Concepts of ageing describe how a population of units or systems improves or deteriorates with age. Many classes of life distributions are categorized and defined in the literature according to their ageing properties. An important aspect of such classifications is that the exponential distribution is nearly always a member of each class. The notion of stochastic ageing is important in any reliability analysis, and many test statistics have been developed for testing exponentiality against vario...

references.text: C. D. Lai, "Tests of univariate and bivariate stochastic ageing", IEEE trans. Reliab., vol. 43, pp. 233-241, 1994.

references.title: Stochastic Ageing and Dependence for Reliability

context.text: There are many aging criteria, so aging distributions are divided into many nonparametric classes according to the type of aging that takes place; see Chapter 2 in [17].

For this reason, many test statistics have been developed in the literature for testing exponentiality (which corresponds to the assumption of no aging) against different aging alternatives, [1], [2], [6], [16], [17], [23].

references.text: C. D. Lai, M. Xie, Stochastic Ageing and Dependence for Reliability, 2006, Springer.

references.title:
Optimal age-replacement policy for nonrepairable products
under renewing free-replacement warranty

context.text: This knowledge is useful, for instance, to choose an appropriate burn-in procedure, or replacement & maintenance policies, because the determination of optimal burn-in time, repair, or replacement age (which minimizes a given cost criterion, or maximizes a given performance measure) depends on the underlying aging class [5], [7], [8], [24].

links.abstract: This paper investigates the effects of a renewing free-replacement warranty on the age replacement policy for a nonrepairable product. For both warranted, and nonwarranted products, cost models are developed, and the corresponding optimal replacement ages are derived such that the long-run expected cost rate is minimized. Furthermore, we show that the optimal replacement age for a warranted product is closer to the end of the warranty period than for a nonwarranted product. Finally, numerical ex...

references.text: R. H. Yeh, G. Chen, M. Chen, "Optimal age-replacement policy for nonrepairable products under renewing free-replacement warranty", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 54, pp. 92-97, 2005.
